  • Sandra Knapp
The Morelloid clade, also known as the black nightshades or “Maurella” (Morella), is one of the 10 major clades within Solanum L. The pantropical clade consists of 75 currently recognised non-spiny herbaceous and suffrutescent species with simple or branched hairs with or without glandular tips, with a centre of distribution in the tropical Andes....

The chloroplast genome sequence of bittersweet (Solanum dulcamara): Plastid genome structure evolution in Solanaceae
Article
Full-text available
  • Apr 2018
  • Ali Amiryousefi
  • Jaakko Hyvönen
  • Peter Poczai
Bittersweet (Solanum dulcamara) is a native Old World member of the nightshade family. This European diploid species can be found from marshlands to high mountainous regions and it is a common weed that serves as an alternative host and source of resistance genes against plant pathogens such as late blight (Phytophthora infestans).   • 2 Answers
Positive selection test?
Question
  • Aug 2017
I have performed a codon based-Z test (MEGA) on a protein coding gene alignment from 30 species to compare the dN-dS values used as a measure of selective pressure indicating neutral mutation rates (dN/dS = 1), positive (dN/dS > 1) and purifying selection (dN/dS < 1). My Z-test rejected neutral and purifying selection and indicated a positive selection with significant p-value (p less than 0.05). I was further interested to find, which codons are under positive selection, so I used HYPHY and various tools within it to find the sites. But HYPHY found no evidence of positive selection at the codon positions. I have also used BUSTED for gene-wide episodic diversifying selection finding no signs, and FUBAR on the alignment to identify sites which have experienced pervasive diversification over the entire phylogenetic tree. This also gave negative results. Then I run aBSREL to test for episodic diversification, this gave strong evidence that episodic diversifying selection was found on one characteristic branch of the tree. Could you give an a reason why the codon based Z tests are indicating positive selection, while other tests don't and instead pointing to episodic diversifying selection on one branch of the tree and possibly what this could mean?
View
  • 3 Answers

The genome size of the diploid is 1000 Mbp, the tetraploid 2200 Mbp and the hexa is 3032 Mbp. What methods can I use or what workflow can I follow?

Projects

Projects (10)
Genome wide identification and characterization of gene families
Project
We want to characterize various gene families and elucidate possible role in biotic and abiotic stresses.
View
Solanaceae plastomes
Project
1. Sequence and/or de novo assemble the complete plastomes of thirteen species to enhance chloroplast genome resources of Solanaceae. 2. To assemble the plastid genome of five Nicotiana species and compare their sequences to gain insight into the plastid genome structure of the genus 3. To infer phylogenetic relationships of the genus Nicotiana and investigate the selection pressures acting on protein-coding genes. 4. To find out the origin of the maternal genome of Aztec tobacco (Nicotiana rustica). 5. To conduct relaxed molecular clock and biogeographical analyses of Nicotiana. 6. To evaluate interspecific variation of plastomes within the selected species of Morelloid clade of Solanum, provide information on the most appropriate molecular chloroplast markers for species identification, and infer the chloroplast phylogenomic relations of selected species of Morelloid clade of Solanum. 7. To report the first representative chloroplast genome sequence of the genus Withania (W. somnifera) and compare it with four other X=12 clade species chloroplast genomes in Solanaceae to get an insight into the evolutionary history of the family. 8. To analyze the phylogenetic relationship of Withania in Solanaceae and to analyze differences in the organization of Withania plastomes such as repeats, indels, and substitutions. 9. To identify mutational hotspots of Nicotiana, Solanum and Withania for the development of robust, authentic and cost-effective markers to infer phylogeny, to resolve taxonomic discrepancies at genus and family level and for barcoding.
View
  • 2 Updates
Evolutionary dynamics of chloroplast genomes in the plant family Araceae
Project
We are interested to provide broad insight into the evolutionary dynamics of the plant family Araceae from genus level to family level.
